questions.text: The spinal cord develops from the______.
questions.solution:
The spinal cord develops from the caudal part of the neural tube.

The nervous system develops from the neurectoderm, the specialized ectoderm overlying the notochord. The neuroectoderm initially thickens to form the neural plate. The neural plate is then converted to a neural groove, followed by a neural tube.

  • The enlarged cranial part of neural tube forms the brain. It has 3 primary vesicles that form forebrain (prosencephalon), midbrain (mesencephalon), and hindbrain (rhombencephalon). 
  • The narrow caudal part of the neural tube forms the spinal cord.

questions.text: Following complete ileal and partial jejunal resection, the patient is most likely to have
questions.solution:
After complete ileal and partial jejunal resection, the patient is likely to have vitamin B12 deficiency.

Vitamin B12 is absorbed in the ileum. Vitamin B12 binds to intrinsic factor, a protein secreted by the parietal cells of the stomach, and the complex is absorbed across the ileal mucosa. Hence after ileal resection, there is impaired absorption of vitamin B12.

Related Pearl: Major Sites of Absorption of Hematopoietic Factors

  • Duodenum + upper jejunum: Iron
  • Jejunum: Folate
  • Terminal Ileum: Vitamin B12

Mnemonic - Dude Is Just Feeling Ill Bro

questions.text: An 8 month-old baby is brought to the pediatric clinic with symptoms of diarrhea, hair loss and failure to thrive. On clinical examination, there is inflammation of the skin around the mouth and the perianal region. The mineral deficiency responsible for this disease is?
questions.solution:
The symptoms and clinical findings, strongly suggest a diagnosis of Acrodermatitis enteropathica which is due to the deficiency of zinc.

It is an autosomal recessive disease due to a defect in zinc absorbing transmembrane protein.

Symptoms:

  • Growth retardation
  • Diarrhea
  • Alopecia
  • Rash involving the extremities, face, and perineum(rash is characterized by vesicular and pustular crusting with scaling and erythema)
  • Gonadal atrophy
  • Muscle wasting
  • Impaired wound healing

questions.text: A 50-year-old HIV seropositive male presents with raised violaceous plaques over the distal portion of the lower limbs. Biopsy shows a lesion composed of proliferating spindle cells along with small vessels and spaces containing red cells. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the histopathological findings are most suggestive of Kaposi sarcoma.

Kaposi sarcoma is a vascular neoplasm caused by human herpesvirus 8 (HHV8) and is highly associated with AIDS (acquired immunodeficiency syndrome).

Classic Kaposi sarcoma occurs in older men of Eastern European and Meditteranean descent and has the following three clinical stages:

  • Patches- red-purple macules on the distal lower extremities
  • Plaques- patches progress to large violaceous raised plaques. Lesions spread proximally.
  • Nodules- Lesions become nodular with more neoplastic features. This stage also progresses to involve nodes and viscera.

The given images show coalescent red-purple macules and plaques of the skin and the histologic appearance of Kaposi sarcoma, demonstrating sheets of proliferating spindle cells:

questions.text:
A 70-year-old woman was diagnosed with right leg cellulitis and was admitted to the hospital for 3 days. She was prescribed clindamycin. Two days after her discharge, she developed diarrhea and abdominal pain. Her temperature was 38.8 degrees Celcius. Her blood reports are given below. What is the most probable etiological agent?
  • Hemoglobin- 12 g/dL
  • WBC count of 18,000/mm3
  • CRP of 160 mg/L
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of a patient with hospital-acquired diarrhea (nosocomial) following antibiotic administration is suggestive of pseudomembranous colitis due to Clostridium difficile. 

Clostridium difficile is the most common cause of infectious diarrhea in nosocomial infection. 

It is the most common antibiotic-associated diarrhea. It is commonly seen in individuals who receive a prolonged antibiotic course, which causes a change in the composition of gastrointestinal microbial flora, leading to colonization of C. difficile.

Clinical features:

  • Lower abdominal pain with loose watery diarrhea.
  • Fever, leukocytosis
  • In some patients, the disease may progress to life-threatening pseudomembranous colitis

Investigations:

  • Nucleic acid amplification tests, including polymerase chain reaction assays, for C. difficile toxin A or B gene in stool 
  • Stool culture in selective media
  • Demonstrating toxin by cell cytotoxin cultures
  • Toxin gene identification by enzyme immunoassay
  • Colonoscopy or sigmoidoscopy reveals a characteristic pseudomembrane.

Nucleic acid amplification tests, including PCR assays, for C. difficile toxin A or B gene in stool, have now been approved for diagnostic purposes and appear to be both rapid and sensitive while retaining high specificity.

Oral vancomycin, metronidazole, and fidaxomicin are used for the treatment of pseudomembranous colitis, depending on its severity. 

First choice treatment of C. difficile colitis:

Severity Treatment
Mild to moderate Oral vancomycin OR fidaxomicin
Severe (WBC >15,000/cu.mm, Creatinine >1.5 times baseline) Oral vancomycin OR fidaxomicin
Severe, complicated (shock, ileus, toxic megacolon) Oral vancomycin + IV metronidazole ± Rectal vancomycin
Recurrent/ multiple episodes Fecal microbiota transplantation (FMT)

 

Other options: Escherichia coli, Norovirus, Rotavirus are all causes of Traveller's diarrhea.

Other causes of Nosocomial diarrhea:

  • Clostridium perfringens,
  • Klebsiella oxytoca,
  • Staphylococcus aureus.

Related Pearl: Diagnostic criteria for Clostridium difficile infection

 

The diagnosis of CDI is based on a combination of clinical criteria:

1.Diarrhea (≥3 unformed stools per 24 h for ≥2 days) with no other recognized cause      

2.Detection of toxins A or B in the stool by PCR or culture

               or               

 Detection of pseudomembranes in the colon

questions.text: Maraviroc is a chemokine receptor antagonist against the following receptor _______
questions.solution: Maraviroc is a chemokine receptor antagonist acting against the CCR5 receptor. It binds to host cell CCR-5 receptor and prevents binding of viral gp-120 to host cells. It is indicated in patients with evidence of infection with predominantly CCR-5 tropic virus.

questions.text: A patient presents to the E.R. with a history of a gunshot wound sustained while on a hunting trip. X-ray findings are as given below. Which of the following weapons is most likely to produce this type of lesion?
questions.solution:
The given radiograph shows birdshot pellets within and around the shattered patella, distal femur, and proximal tibia. The wound shown in the image is most likely to have been caused by a close-range shotgun injury to the knee.

The ammunition for the shotgun is a cartridge made of a cardboard or plastic cylinder fitted into a metal base. The base carries a percussion detonator that is struck by the spring-loaded firing pin when the trigger is pulled.  The primer is located in the percussion cup and contains the detonator.  The cartridge contains a charge of propellant (gunpowder), above which are ‘wads’ or pistons of felt, and cardboard or plastic discs, or both. Above these is the charge of shot (pellets), which varies greatly in number and size, finally covered by a card or plastic disc.

The image given below shows the entry wound in the case of a shotgun. There is a central round hole, with multiple pellet holes scattered around the central hole. This wound is most likely to have been caused by a shotgun from a range of 1-5 m.

questions.text: Symptoms of sinusitis includes all except
questions.solution: Diplopia is not seen in sinusitis.

questions.text: The corneal epithelium is composed of_______.
questions.solution:
The corneal epithelium is made up of stratified squamous non-keratinized epithelium.

Layers of the cornea

  • Epithelium (Stratified squamous non-keratinized epithelium)
    • A single layer of columnar basal cells attached by hemidesmosomes to an underlying basement
      membrane
    • Limbal stem cells are located at the corneoscleral limbus, possibly in the palisades of Vogt. Deficiency may result in chronic epithelial defects and "conjunctivalization" (epithelial instability, vascularization, and the appearance of goblet cells)
    • Complete turnover of corneal epithelial cells occurs in about 7–10 days.
  • Bowman’s membrane
    • Acellular superficial layer of the stroma formed from collagen fibers.
    • Does not regenerate
  • Stroma (Thickest layer)
    • Makes up 90% of corneal thickness
    • Contains chondroitin sulphate (dermatan sulphate) and keratan sulphate.
    • The stroma can scar, but cannot regenerate the subsequent damage.
  • Dua’s layer (Newly discovered, toughest layer)
  • Descemet’s membrane
    • Ends peripherally as Schwalbe’s ring
    • Has regenerative potential
  • Endothelium (Most metabolically active layer)
    • Does not regenerate
    • Endothelial cells maintain corneal deturgescence

questions.text: Which of the following steps of disaster management is in correct order?
questions.solution:
Disaster Management includes three aspects:

1. Disaster impact and response: 

  Involves immediate management of mass casualties

  • Search, rescue, and first-aid
  • Field care
  • Triage
  • Tagging
  • Identification of dead

2. Rehabilitation or recovery:

   Involves restoration of the pre-disaster conditions

  • Water supply
  • Basic sanitation and personal hygiene
  • Food safety
  • Vector control

3. Mitigation: Measures designed either to prevent hazards from causing disaster or to reduce the effects of the disaster. This also includes preparedness for any impending disasters or in disaster-prone areas.

questions.text: Below is a diagram depicting the natural history of the disease. Which point marks the onset of symptoms?
questions.solution:
Point C represents a point where signs and symptoms appear.

Various points marked in the image represent the following:

Point A: Entry of infectious agent into the host.

Point B: Pathological and physiological changes occur in the stage of the subclinical phase. These changes are induced by the causative agent but are not sufficient enough to cause clinical signs and symptoms.

Point C: Marks onset of clinical signs and symptoms.

Point D: Usual time of diagnosis at which clinical signs and symptoms are well evident.

questions.text: In a population study, the value of the mean is 200. If the standard deviation is 20, 68% of the population will lie between?
questions.solution:
68% of the population will lie between 180- 220.

In a normal distribution curve, 68% of the values lie within the median +/- 1 standard deviation and the mean=median=mode. Since the mean = 200 and the standard deviation = 20:

68% of population will lie between Median +/- 1SD, that is, 200 +/- 20 = 180-220

95% of population lies between Median+/-2SD, 200+/- 2*20 = 160- 240

99% of population lies between Median+/-3SD, 200+/- 3*20 = 140- 260

Related Pearl: Normal Distribution

  • Normal distribution is the most widely used continuous distribution.
  • It is also called bell curve (bell shaped) or Gaussian distribution after a mathematician named Karl Friedrich Gauss.
  • The following is an image of three different types of normal distributions.
  • Normal distributions are defined by two parameters: the mean and the standard deviation.
  • The mean, median and mode are all equal in a normal distribution.
  • All normal distributions are symmetric and have bell-shaped density curves with a single peak.
  • Exactly half of the values are to the left of the centre and the other half to the right.
  • The total area under the curve is 1.
  • The density of a normal distribution is more around the centre and less around the tails.
  • There is no skew in the curve.
  • Looking at the figure below, we can understand the empirical rule of a normal distribution which states that:
    • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 1 SD).
    • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 2 SD).
    • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 3 SD).
  • Many data like blood pressure, heights, IQ scores, etc. form a normal distribution.
  • A standard normal distribution is a normal distribution with a mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1.

questions.text: In a patient with suspected stable angina, which of the following findings are likely to be present?

choices.text: CK-MB is elevated ; Troponin T is normal
Troponin I is elevated ; Myoglobin is normal
Myoglobin is elevated ; CK-MB is normal
Troponin I is normal ; CK-MB is normal

questions.solution:
The levels of cardiac markers remain unchanged in stable and unstable angina as there is no necrosis of cardiac myocytes.

The clinical presentations of ischemic heart disease can be broadly classified into: 

  • Chronic coronary syndrome (CCS) - this includes
    • Stable angina - this is an episodic angina that occurs with predictable severity, frequency, and threshold of precipitation by stressors, and is relieved by rest and nitrates  
  • Acute coronary syndrome (ACS) - this includes
    • Unstable angina - this is diagnosed in patients with symptoms suggestive of an ACS with no elevation of biomarkers
    • Myocardial infarction - it is the necrosis and death of a portion of the myocardium due to prolonged ischemia. The cardiac biomarkers are elevated in this condition

questions.text:
A 52-year-old man presents with oliguria, abdominal distension, and pedal edema. His medical records show long-standing cirrhosis with multiple hospitalisations for ascites and hepatic encephalopathy. His lab reports are given below. What is the best treatment for his condition?

AST- 148 U/L

ALT- 64 U/L

Total bilirubin- 8.9 mg/dL

Sr. Creatinine- 7.6 mg/dL

Blood urea nitrogen- 84 mg/dL
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of hepatorenal syndrome. The best treatment modality for it is liver transplantation.

Hepatorenal syndrome is characterised by a rise in:

  • AST
  • ALT
  • Total bilirubin
  • Serum creatinine
  • Blood urea nitrogen (BUN).

Management of hepatorenal syndrome include:

  • Norepinephrine
  • Octreotide
  • Terlipressin
  • Midodrine
  • Intravenous albumin 
  • Liver transplantation- definitive treatment

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman came with a headache and decreased urine output. On examination her BP was 150/90mmhg and abdominal bruits were heard.  Renal angiography was done. Which of the following statements is not true regarding the condition shown in the image given below:

choices.text: Most common site of involvement is renal artery
Most commonly affected peripheral artery is subclavian artery

questions.solution:
The image shows "strings of beads appearance" on CT angiography which is characteristic of fibromuscular dysplasia. The most common limb artery affected is iliac arteries.

Fibromuscular dysplasia:

  • Segmentally affected, non-atheromatous and dysplastic type of angiopathy
  • Predominantly affects females
  • The most common subtype is medial fibroplasia
  • The most common site of involvement is renal > carotid > limb arteries
  • The most common limb artery affected is the iliac arteries.
  • CT  angiography shows a ‘string of beads’ appearance.
  • Can also present as renal aneurysms.

questions.text: A 71-year-old man presents to the OPD with high-grade fever, productive cough. On examination, the respiratory rate was found to be 32/ min, heart rate of 102/ min, and blood pressure of 90/60 mmHg. How will you manage this patient?

choices.text: Admit to ICU and treat with azithromycin and ceftriaxone
Admit to the ward and treat with levofloxacin and doxycycline
Treat him on OP basis with azithromycin and ceftriaxone
Admit to the ward and treat with azithromycin and levofloxacin

questions.solution: The given clinical scenario is highly suggestive of lobar pneumonia and the patient belongs to a CURB-65 score of 3. The patient can be best managed by a combination of azithromycin and ceftriaxone in an ICU setting. After culture sensitivity, specific management is done.

questions.text: A child presents with pain and swelling in the right side of his scrotum and testicular torsion is suspected. Which is the most appropriate management?

choices.text: Immediate exploration on both symptomatic and asymptomatic side
Immediate exploration on symptomatic side only
Delayed exploration on both symptomatic and asymptomatic side
Delayed exploration on symptomatic side only

questions.solution:
In a case of suspected testicular torsion, immediate exploration needs to be done on both the symptomatic as well as the asymptomatic side.

In testicular torsion, the blood supply to the testicle is compromised due to the twisting of the spermatic cord within the tunica vaginalis, resulting in ischemia of the epididymis and the testis.

At the time of surgical exploration contralateral testes also must be explored and fixed to the dartos fascia due to the possibility that the same anatomic defect allowing torsion exists on the contralateral side.

More than 80% of testes can be salvaged if surgery is performed within 6 hours. If the testis is found to be necrosed on scrotal exploration, orchidectomy of the necrosed testis and orchidopexy of the contralateral testis is done.

questions.text: True statement about intermittent claudication:

choices.text: Most commonly felt in the calf muscles
Day to day distance is variable
Relived after getting out of bed

questions.solution:
Intermittent claudication is most commonly felt in the calf muscles because of the involvement of the superficial femoral artery in chronic vascular occlusive disease.

Intermittent claudication is the debilitating cramp-like pain felt in the leg muscles due to reduced blood flow brought on by peripheral arterial disease. It usually signifies mild to moderate chronic vascular occlusive disease.

The pain classically occurs during activity and is relieved with rest. The distance that a patient can walk without stopping till the pain is experienced in the muscles is known as claudication distance. This distance varies only slightly from day to day.

Rest pain signifies critical limb ischemia, occurring due to the worsening of perfusion to the muscle.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient presents to the clinic with a history of pain during defecation for the past 2 months and the presence of blood-streaked stools. He has had a history of constipation for 5 months. On examination, there is a presence of a sentinel tag at the anal orifice. Due to extreme pain, a digital rectal examination is avoided. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient is anal fissure.

This case scenario with a history of chronic constipation, and the presence of sentinel tags on examination, suggests a diagnosis of anal fissure.

An anal fissure is a longitudinal split in the anoderm of the distal anal canal. A chronic anal fissure frequently is associated with :

  • Sentinel tag externally
  • Hypertrophied anal papillae internally
  • Anal ulcer overlying the internal sphincter

Clinical features:

It is usually seen in the young but it can occur at any age with equal sex predilection. Severe pain associated with defecation resolves spontaneously and reappears during the next evacuation. It may even be associated with the passage of fresh blood noticed on tissue after wiping. Most of the fissures are located in the posterior midline, with the rest being located in the anterior midline. Fissures located anywhere around the anal circumference can be possible due to other diseases like HIV, TB, syphilis, Crohn's disease, or carcinoma.

Treatment of anal fissure:

  • The focus is the normalization of bowel habits. Bowel softeners, dietary fibers, and adequate water should be recommended.
  • Medical therapy involves the topical application of glyceryl trinitrate. It releases nitric oxide and relaxes the internal anal sphincter. This reduces spasm and pain and improves vasculature to promote healing.
  • Surgical therapy is recommended for chronic fissures that have failed medical therapy. Lateral internal sphincterotomy is the procedure of choice where a portion of the internal sphincter is divided away from the fissure. 

Other options

Option A- Anal fistula is usually associated with pain and intermittent purulent discharge. On examination, an external opening in the perineum can be found which opens internally in the anal canal.

Option C- Hemorrhoids present with painless bleeding which is separate from the stool. Pain is not a common feature and is present if hemorrhoids are prolapsed.

Option D- Rectal prolapse presents as a mass protruding out of the anal canal. It is more in females and may be associated with fecal incontinence.

questions.text: In the given picture of a Foley’s catheter, what is the function of the tube marked ‘A’?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a three-way Foley's catheter. The tube marked ‘A’ is used for continuous irrigation of the bladder to remove debris & blood clots. This is most commonly used after any prostate surgery or conditions with bleeding in the bladder.

The central tube is used for the drainage of urine and the tube on the right is used for inflating the balloon. 

Related Pearl: Foley's catheter

A Foley catheter is a thin, sterile tube inserted into the bladder to drain urine. Because it can be left in place in the bladder for a period of time, it is also called an indwelling catheter.

French scale corresponds to the external circumference in millimetres. French size divided by 3 will give the outer diameter of the catheter. 

Fr. size = 3 x d, where d is the outer diameter in mm. 

A 3 Fr. catheter will have a circumference of approximately 3 mm and a diameter of 1 mm. 

Note:

Colour of the foleys is the colour at the baloon port as shown in the figure below

questions.text: Diagnostic laparoscopy was performed on a patient who presented with infertility. During the procedure, the surgeon notices powder burn spots over the pelvic viscera. The diagnosis would be?
questions.solution:
Powder burn spots over pelvic viscera is seen in pelvic endometriosis. 

Typically, there are small black dots, the so-called powder burns/gunshot appearance seen on the serosal surfaces of the peritoneum. They are black, dark brown, or bluish nodules or can be small cysts containing old hemorrhage surrounded by a variable degree of fibrosis.

Other pathology in Endometriosis:

  • Peritoneal cavity: contains yellowish-brown fluid which has prostaglandins responsible for the pain of endometriosis.
  • Ovary: Chocolate cyst (True cyst with columnar epithelium lining)

Powder burn appearance:

questions.text: Pap smear is ________
questions.solution:
Pap smear is a screening test. In case of positive test further investigations should be done.

Pap Smear Schedule

  • Time for initiation: 21 years, regardless of the age of first sexual intercourse.
  • Women aged 21-29 years: Every 3 years(earlier it was done annually)
  • Women aged 30-65 years: Pap test + HPV testing every 5 years.
  • Women should stop having cervical cancer screening after the age of 65 years. If suspicious PAP, screening till 75 years.
  • HIV+ women: annual checkup until three consecutive negative tests followed by testing every 3 years for life.
  • HPV DNA testing in combination with PAP improves the sensitivity of screening.

Ayres spatula and endocervical brush are the instruments used for the pap test.

Ayres spatula:

  • One end is blunt and the other end is bifid.
  • Blunt end is used to take samples for vaginal cytology.
  • Bifid end is used to take Pap smear

Endocervical brush:

questions.text: A woman comes to your clinic for a follow-up. An obstetric scan was ordered which showed a 12-week intra-uterine pregnancy with a complete placenta previa. Which of the following is false about this condition?

choices.text: Painful recurrent vaginal bleeding can occur
The size of the uterus corresponds to gestational age
Fetal condition is generally good until bleeding is severe
Vaginal delivery cannot be tried in this lady

questions.solution:
Painless recurrent vaginal bleeding is seen in placenta previa.

Clinical features of placenta previa:

  • Bleeding per vaginum - sudden onset, painless, recurrent, bright red in colour, sometimes a history of warning haemorrhage is present
  • Uterus - relaxed, soft, no tenderness, size proportional to the period of gestation
  • Floating head i.e., persistent displacement of fetal head as it cannot be pushed down into the pelvis
  • Fetal heart sound - present. Fetal condition is generally good until bleeding is severe
  • Stallworthy sign - seen in the low-lying placenta, especially the posterior type. Slowing of fetal heart rate (FHR) on pressing the head down into the pelvis, which recovers promptly as pressure is relieved, is called the Stallworthy sign.

Central placenta previa is a contraindication for vaginal delivery. Cesarean delivery is recommended for all patients with placenta previa where it is located within 2 cm of the internal os. Vaginal delivery may be considered when the placental edge is located 2-3 cm away from the internal os.

questions.text: The most common soft tissue sarcoma in the pediatric age group is______.
questions.solution:
Rhabdomyosarcoma, a tumor of striated skeletal muscle, is the most common pediatric soft tissue sarcoma.

The most common sites are- head and neck (25%) > genitourinary tract (24%) > extremities (19%) > orbit (9%).

questions.text: A patient has a history of a road traffic accident 2 years back, and has developed pain and swelling now at the same site. His X-ray image is shown in the image given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the X-ray image are suggestive of chronic osteomyelitis of the tibia.

Chronic osteomyelitis may occur by direct inoculation of the infective organism during trauma (like road traffic accident). The infection continues to thrive within the bone leading to alternating quiescent and flare up stages of chronic osteomyelitis.

The radiographic image shows oval-shaped sequestrum and periosteal new bone formation surrounding the sequestrum known as involucrum. 

The characteristic radiographic features of other conditions given are:

Osteogenic sarcoma - Sun-burst appearance, Codman's triangle

Ewing's sarcoma - Onion skin appearance

Multiple myeloma - Punched out lesions

questions.text: Sexual identity does not depend on which of the following factors?
questions.solution:
Sexual identity does not depend on upbringing. Sexual identity is the pattern of a person’s biological sexual characteristics.

It depends on the following:

  • Chromosomes
  • External and internal genitalia
  • Hormonal composition
  • Gonads
  • Secondary sex characteristics

questions.text: The device shown in the given image is used for the monitoring of:
questions.solution:
The given image depicts a pulse oximeter. Pulse oximetry is used for monitoring pulse rate and oxygen saturation of a patient.

A small sensor is placed on the finger, toe, earlobe, or another convenient place.

The relative absorption of light by oxyhemoglobin (HbO) and deoxyhemoglobin is assessed by measuring the amount of red and infrared light emerging from tissues traversed by light rays and processed by the device, producing an oxygen saturation level.

Pulse oximetry does not measure the absolute content or the partial pressures of oxygen or carbon dioxide.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true regarding piebaldism?

choices.text: Small spots of hyperpigmentation can also be seen

questions.solution:
White forelock is quite common in Piebaldism.

Piebaldism:

  • Autosomal dominant benign condition, it has mutations in c‐KIT.
  • Well-defined irregular hypopigmented macules with an absence of melnocytes.
  • Small spots of hyperpigmentation are also seen within hypopigmented patches or on normal skin. 
  • It is often associated with a V-shaped leucoderma on mid-forehead.
  • Both sexes are equally affected.
  • Piebaldism can be distinguished from vitiligo because of the neonatal presence of white patches.
  • Epidermal cell or skin grafting is the treatment.

questions.text: A worker from the cement industry got a chest X-ray as a part of his routine health check-up. What could cause the findings in the given chest X-ray?
questions.solution:
Asbestosis could cause the findings in the given chest X-ray.

The given X-ray shows irregular opacities, which appear to be pleural thickenings i.e., pleural plaques. The sign along with a history of working in the cement industry suggests a diagnosis of asbestosis. It predominantly affects the lower lobes of the lung, in contrast to other forms of pneumoconiosis, which affect the upper lobes. 

Workers of the cement, shipping, and textile industries are at a higher risk of developing asbestosis. Asbestos tends to involve the pleura first. The earliest manifestation is benign asbestosis related pleural effusion. With time, the plaques are calcified resulting in the formation of thick pleural plaques. The pleural thickenings can be seen on the X-ray. This is the “holly leaf sign”.

Lung parenchymal involvement occurs after years of exposure (at least 10 years). They present with cough and exertional dyspnoea. Pulmonary function testing in asbestosis typically shows a restrictive pattern with a decrease in both lung volumes and diffusing capacity.

questions.text: A woman diagnosed with DCIS underwent surgery and is now posted for adjuvant radiotherapy with external beam radiotherapy. Which of the following isotopes is commonly used for the same?
questions.solution:
Cobalt-60 isotope is used for external beam radiotherapy (EBRT).

External beam radiotherapy is given as follows:

  • Cobalt machine - Co-60 produces gamma rays. It emits radiation of energy 1.25 MeV.
  • LINAC (linear accelator) - X-ray beams are generated to provide ionising radiation.

The energy spectrum used in radiotehrapy is classified as follows:

  • Orthovoltage - 200-500kV x-rays are produced. It is used to treat skin conditions. 
  • Megavoltage - 1-25 MV x-rays are produced. These are used in modern radiotherapy.
